I realize this is no longer a JUnit topic, but I
couldn't resist adding my =
2 cents (and I'm quite broke,
so I won't be adding any more 2 cents):

> Pr=
ocess definitions don't write software; people do.

  Right, but process de=
finitions help people take care of
  the more mundane tasks in software dev=
elopment. Perhaps
  every heretofore uncharted business domain may provide
=
  artistic freedom for a software developer, but pretty soon,
  it becomes =
yet another "patternizable", "automated testable"
  piece of software.
> 
>=
  From what I understand the goal of CMM is to define a 
> process that eve=
n 
> a monkey could follow. Monkeys do not write software; people do.

  pe=
rhaps the monkey refers to "code monkeys"...
  Again, my point is that a la=
rge part of software being built today
  is grunt-work, which can and shoul=
d be codified in a process.
> 
> It drives towards more uniform results, ce=
rtainly; but I don't know 
> about "better software".
  
  At the end, if y=
ou're saying the concept of the CMM is BS, I don't
agree. The very fact tha=
t we're using JUnit and other tools to 
complement our laziness (laziness b=
eing a compliment, of course, in
software development) is evidence that we =
are trying to get from
Initial to Repeatable (this word is JUnit all the wa=
y) to Defined
to Managed to Optimized (refactor mercilessly).
if you're say=
ing the process (documentation, documentation and more
documentation) is fl=
awed, I'm with you.

Finally, I just took a look at http://www.sei.cmu.edu =
and found out 
that they're sunsetting the CMM and moving to CMMI, so maybe=
 they
did find out that most people out here cared two hoots about the
proc=
ess...

regards,
Nilesh
